Article.ArticleTitle: Female Gender as a Risk Factor for Adverse Outcomes Following Carotid Revascularization.

Abstract.AbstractText: We aim to identify gender differences in complications following carotid surgery. Our primary endpoint is the incidence of perioperative stroke, myocardial infarction and mortality. Secondary endpoints include restenosis and reintervention rates.
All patients undergoing carotid endarterectomy from July 2003 to May 2016 were reviewed. The Society for Vascular Surgery Carotid Reporting Standards were used as a guideline for data collection.

Over 13 years, 9585 patients with carotid disease were referred to our institution. 690 procedures were performed (633 carotid endarterectomy, 54 carotid angioplasty and stenting, 3 bypass). Of these 633 carotid endarterectomy procedures, 31.8% (201) were in females and 68.2% (432) were in males. In the perioperative period, female gender was found to be an independent predictor of stroke (OR 8.597, 95% CI 0.967-76.429, P=.041), restenosis (OR 2.103, 95% CI 1.445-3.060, P<.001) and reintervention (OR 6.448, 95% CI 1.313-31.667, P=.019). Mortality and cardiac morbidity did not significantly differ between genders. 10-year stroke-free survival was 98.0% in females and 99.1% in males (log rank P=.259). 10-year restenosis-free survival was 77.6% (45 of 201) in females and 89.4% (45 of 425) in males (log rank P<.001). 10-year reintervention-free survival was 97.0% in females and 99.5% in males (log rank P=.008). Female gender was not an independent predictor of myocardial infarction (P=.713) and mortality (P=.856), respectively. The mean follow-up time was 47.06+37.48 months with a median follow-up time of 43 months [IQR 14.0-72.5].

Female gender was an independent predictor of postoperative stroke, restenosis and reintervention. Symptom status at the time of surgery and type of closure of the arteriotomy did not influence development of stroke in female patients.
